content: Precious Myles Garrett, a right-hand dominant children's social worker, presents with left wrist pain that is more bothersome than the masses and wakes her up at night. She reports a history of a mass at the dorsal radial aspect of her left wrist and another at the dorsal ulnar aspect of the left thumb MCP joint. Both masses have been fluctuating in size in the past but have remained constant recently. She was evaluated by her rheumatologist who performed X-rays and an ultrasound of the wrist. She is seeking evaluation and treatment for her symptoms.
title: HPI Spencer

content: left upper extremity skin is clean, dry and intact without anything by my diagnosis. There is a pea-sized mass over the first dorsal compartment. No tenderness or location over the mass. It is mobile and non-tender. Negative Finklestein, no pain with resisted thumb extension. Um, there is a mass at the dorsal ulnar aspect of the thumb MCP joint that is non-mobile and very minimally tender. Excellent range of motion at the thumb MCP. No tenderness or location at the A1 point, no locking or catching.
title: Musculoskeletal

content: X-rays show an osteophyte at the thumb MCP joint. Ultrasound demonstrates a bony avulsion fragment versus osteophyte at the dorsal aspect of the MCP joint of the thumb. Ultrasound of the wrist demonstrates a retinacular cyst superficial to the first dorsal compartment sheath.
title: Imaging Results

content: - left first dorsal compartment wrist cyst
title: Assessment

content: Aspiration versus biopsy of the wrist mass.
Return to clinic in six weeks to follow up.
title: Plan
